channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine News: Russian Strike on Central Ukrainian City Kills at Least 23
item.description: The attack in Vinnytsia is the latest to hit a civilian target without an apparent military aim. The W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner returned to a Russian court after pleading guilty to drug charges.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Gaps in Arms Supplies to Ukraine Point to Countries’ Divergent Strategies
item.description: Beyond logistical issues, the uneven flow of arms to Ukraine hints at differences among allies about whether Russia should be punished or eventually accommodated.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops fired a a U.S.-supplied M777 howitzer at Russian positions last month in the Donetsk region.

item.title: Why the Latest Palestinian Leader in the West Bank Is Unpopular
item.description: Hussein al-Sheikh is considered a possible successor to Mahmoud Abbas, 87, the Palestinian Authority president. But as a liaison to Israel, some critics call him a “spokesman of the occupation.”
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hussein al-Sheikh has become the focus of a debate among Palestinians about the vision and legitimacy of their leaders.

item.title: Philippine Mayors Tell City Workers to Smile or Face Discipline
item.description: “Frowning is not allowed in the municipality!” said the mayor of the town of Mulanay. Many residents support his new policy.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Jason Gutierrez

item.title: Italy’s Unity Government Teeters, as Mario Draghi Offers to Resign
item.description: The country’s president refused to accept the prime minister’s resignation, leaving the country in political limbo.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mario Draghi, center, speaking at the Italian Senate, in Rome in June. This week, he said, “A government does not work with ultimatums.”

item.title: Sri Lanka’s President Resigns After Months of Protest
item.description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka submitted his resignation by email from Singapore, although the political uncertainty continues.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall, Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Thursday night cheered the news that the country’s president had resigned.

item.title: Biden’s Talks With Israeli Leader Highlight a Split Over Iran
item.description: After a meeting in Jerusalem, Israel’s caretaker prime minister, Yair Lapid, said nations must promise to act if the Iranians “continue to develop their nuclear program,” pushing for President Biden to go beyond his declared position.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Biden’s Saudi Lesson: The Only Path Runs Through M.B.S.
item.description: President Biden tried to isolate Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman over human rights abuses. Now, the United States needs Saudi Arabia, and Mr. Biden is about to visit.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia. Concerns over oil prices and Iran’s nuclear capabilities are forcing the president to seek help from the kingdom and its de facto ruler.

item.title: France Faces a Mustard Shortage
item.description: A perfect storm of climate change, a European war and Covid have left the French scrambling for alternatives.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Mustard on sale in Dijon, France, last year. While Dijon mustard is as irreplaceable as it is indispensable, lately French diners have had to do without.

item.title: Ex-Iranian Official Convicted by Swedish Court for Prison Executions
item.description: Swedish prosecutors pursued the case against the official, Hamid Noury, for crimes in his homeland, and he was sentenced to life for his role in the 1988 deaths of thousands of opposition members.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Chris Anderson/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: People celebrated on Thursday outside Stockholm District Court at the news of a life sentence for Hamid Noury.

item.title: Priests in Ukrainian Orthodox Church Come Under Suspicion
item.description: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church was once a dominant force in the country, but now officials suspect that some priests may be collaborating with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Oleksandr Chubko and Vera Mironova
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Priests in the Ukrainian Orthodox Church conducted a Mass in Kyiv, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Seeks to Dispel Worries of Second-Term Drift
item.description: In a televised Bastille Day interview, the French president sought to reassure a country buffeted by rising inflation, scorching temperatures and uncertain political waters.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron at the annual Bastille Day military parade in Paris. For the second time in his presidency, he gave a traditional Bastille Day televised interview.

item.title: I.M.F. and Pakistan Reach Deal on Loan Program
item.description: The long-awaited agreement could pave the way for the release of $1.17 billion to Pakistan as the country grapples with high inflation and political instability.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan’s political party protesting against rising inflation in Karachi, Pakistan, last month.

item.title: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to Sexual Assault
item.description: The Oscar-winning actor will face a trial in June 2023 — a rare example of a celebrity #MeToo case reaching that stage in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: The actor Kevin Spacey arrived for his appearance at the Old Bailey, a courthouse in central London.

item.title: The many parties involved complicate war crimes investigations.
item.description: Russian attacks on civilians have underscored the need to hold war crimes to account. But the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court warned against a “stampede” of investigations.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Thursday’s rocket strike on Vinnytsia, Ukraine, was the latest Russian attack that seemed to target a civilian area of a Ukrainian city.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russian strikes on Ukrainian civilians.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Firefighters, police officers and rescue workers at the site of a missile strike in Vinnytsia, Ukraine, on Thursday that led to at least 23 deaths and dozens of hospitalizations.

item.title: Sharp Drop in Childhood Vaccinations Threatens Millions of Lives
item.description: Pandemic lockdowns, misinformation campaigns, conflicts, climate crises and other problems diverted resources and contributed to the largest backslide in routine immunization in 30 years.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Polio vaccinations at a bus station in Jammu, India, in February. India, Nigeria, Indonesia, Ethiopia and the Philippines recorded the highest numbers of children who had missed out on vaccines.

item.title: Biden and Israel Remain Divided on Handling Iran’s Nuclear Program
item.description: Amid declarations of the strong friendship between Israel and the United States, the differing approaches to the best way to stop Iran’s nuclear program were evident on Mr. Biden’s trip to Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Yair Lapid of Israel at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: Strikes on Civilians Deep in Ukraine Show Russia’s Lethal Reach
item.description: Missiles struck Vinnytsia, hundreds of miles from the front lines, and other cities, claiming dozens of lives, as Russia keeps up pressure despite pausing its eastern offensive.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Firefighters, police officers and rescue workers at the site of a missile strike in Vinnytsia, Ukraine, on Thursday that led to at least 23 deaths and dozens of hospitalizations.

item.title: Israeli Security Officials Are Divided Over Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: Though the government has opposed any deal with Iran, officials in the Israeli military and its intelligence wing are arguing in favor of a treaty.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A 2019 photo showing the heavy-water reactor in Arak. Tehran insists its nuclear program is strictly for power generation and other civilian uses, but Israel has never given credence to those assertions.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Sri Lanka’s President Resigns
item.description: Plus President Biden treads carefully in Israel and Italy’s government nears collapse.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters celebrated after returning the prime minister's office, which they had been occupying, to the control of the army in Colombo, Sri Lanka on Thursday.

item.title: Random Virus Testng Restarts for International Travelers in Major Canadian Airports
item.description: The country’s mandatory testing program was paused last month as the government worked to shift the testing out of Canada’s busy airport terminals.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Since the beginning of the pandemic, air travel has been the focus of heightened concern for transmission of the coronavirus.

item.title: In an era of alphabet soup diplomacy, Biden is adding ingredients.
item.description: Unsettled times have brought a proliferation of new clusters of various countries, and the acronyms that come with them.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden has contributed to a growth in diplomatic jargon. New alliances in his time as POTUS include IPEF, MEAD and now I2U2.

item.title: W.H.O. Warns Against ‘Apathy’ in Efforts to Contain Covid in Africa
item.description: The warning came two days after the W.H.O., a United Nations agency, declared that Covid-19 was still a global public health emergency that was not going anywhere.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: W.H.O. officials warned of the danger of relaxing public health precautions for events that draw large crowds. Fans filled a stadium in Pretoria, South Africa, for a rugby test match on July 2.

item.title: What are the Maccabiah Games?
item.description: Israel’s biggest sporting event, which President Biden is scheduled to attend on Thursday evening, is often referred to as the Jewish Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: President Biden, center, attended the opening ceremonies of the Maccabiah Games in Jerusalem on Thursday, alongside Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, left, and prime minister, Yair Lapid.

item.title: Britain Braces for ‘Exceptionally’ Hot Weather
item.description: The Met Office issued an amber warning for extreme heat this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: People cool off in the River Darent in Eynsford, in southeastern England, on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Calls for a ‘Lasting Negotiated Peace’ Between Israel and Palestinians
item.description: He also reiterated his calls for a two-state solution to the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Palestinians protesting against President Biden’s planned visit to the West Bank in Nablus on Thursday.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s case shows the limits of American power.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Brittney Griner being escorted to a courtroom for a hearing, in Khimki outside Moscow, Russia, last week.

item.title: What Is the I2U2?
item.description: The name of a new partnership between India, Israel, the United Arab Emirates and the United States refers to the first letters of the four countries’ names in English.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: During the first I2U2 meeting, on Thursday, President Biden and Israel’s prime minister, Yair Lapid, spoke on video with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed of the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: The Semiconductor Problem
item.description: The military relies on advanced semiconductors. The U.S. doesn’t make any.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Chips on display in Taiwan.

item.title: ‘Putin’s War Must Be a Strategic Failure,’ Biden Says in Israel
item.description: Ukraine policy has been a point of friction between Israel and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing at Russian forces in Donetsk Province last month.

item.title: Lapid Urges Biden to Put Pressure on Iran About Nuclear Program
item.description: Prime Minister Yair Lapid asked the U.S. to show Iran that it would take military action if Tehran continued its nuclear enrichment program, highlighting Israel’s opposition to U.S.-backed efforts to persuade Iran through diplomacy alone.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Isabel Kershner and Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden and Israel’s prime minister, Yair Lapid, at a news conference in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: Biden’s Relationship With Netanyahu Blows Hot and Cold
item.description: The U.S. president has often spoken fondly of Israel’s former prime minister, but relations between the two have also had low points.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, left, who was then Israel’s prime minister, and Joseph R. Biden Jr., who was then vice president, at a joint meeting of Congress in 2011.

item.title: Israel Is Between Governments. Will Biden’s Visit Help Yair Lapid?
item.description: President Biden’s visit during an Israeli election campaign may have been unavoidable, given that voters are heading to the polls for a fifth time in under four years.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: President Biden and Israel’s Prime Minister, Yair Lapid, at Ben Gurion Airport on Wednesday.

item.title: Witnesses Testify in Brittney Griner Trial, Which Is Expected to Resume Friday
item.description: The case of an American sports star at the mercy of Russian justice has rippled across the world amid criticism from Washington that she has been wrongfully detained.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Ivan Nechepurenko, Tania Ganguli and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Brittney Griner appeared in a courtroom outside Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Gas prices are falling.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gasoline prices have declined 28 days in a row.

item.title: U.S. Accuses Russia of Large-Scale Ukrainian Deportations
item.description: Ukrainian officials have long sounded the alarm on Russia’s deportations, but U.S. officials had previously been vague about their scale.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: A bus carrying Ukrainians evacuated in May from the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol arriving at in the village of Bezimenne, nearer to the Russian border, in May.

item.title: Differing views of a Ukrainian nationalist’s role in the Holocaust expose divisions over the past.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Ukraine dismissed Andrij Melnyk, Ukraine’s ambassador to Germany, last weekend after in interview in which he defended a nationalist Ukrainian leader who collaborated with the Nazis, and whose followers took part in massacres of Jews and Poles.

item.title: In Pictures: Sri Lanka’s Protesters Persist After President’s Departure
item.description: Many digesting the news of Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s exit appeared to relish witnessing a monumental day in the country’s history.
item.dc:creator: Atul Loke and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters took control of the prime minister’s office in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden, Battered at Home, Basks in Unvarnished Praise in Israel
item.description: The U.S. president, on the first day of a trip to the Mideast, received the sort of rapturous welcome he can only dream about in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: President Biden with his arm around Isaac Herzog, Israel’s president, as he talks with two Holocaust survivors at Yad Vashem in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: Cardinal Cláudio Hummes, Close Ally of Pope Francis, Dies at 87
item.description: An advocate for the poor, he was a force behind the progressive turn taken by many Latin American Catholics in the 1970s and ’80s.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Cardinal Cláudio Hummes in 2006. He blended doctrinal conservatism with social progressivism and insisted that the Roman Catholic Church lift up people on the margins.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Sri Lanka’s Leader Flees
item.description: Plus President Biden visits Israel, and negotiations continue over Ukraine’s blocked grain.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protestors took control of the prime minister’s office yesterday, as well as the state broadcaster.

item.title: Hawaii, the last state with an indoor mask mandate for public schools, will make masks optional.
item.description: Masks will become optional in Hawaii’s schools when the new academic year starts on Aug. 1, as the state tries for “a more normal classroom experience this fall,” a state health official said.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Desks arranged for social distancing in a classroom at Aikahi Elementary School in Kailua, Hawaii, in 2020. Hawaii kept an indoor mask mandate for public schools in effect throuigh the 2021-2022 school year.

item.title: Sri Lanka in Chaos as President Flees and Protesters Reject Interim Leader
item.description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa fled, protesters angered by an economic meltdown overran the interim leader’s offices, and it was unclear who, if anyone, was in charge.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall, Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters stormed the prime minister’s offices in Colombo, Sri Lanka, after the president fled the country on Wednesday.

item.title: Studies Probe Adenovirus Link to Childhood Hepatitis Cases
item.description: Two new papers add to the circumstantial evidence that a common childhood virus might be involved in the rare hepatitis cases, but many questions remain.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: M. Wurtz/Biozentrum, University of Basel, via Science Source
item.media:description: A colorized transmission electron micrograph of an adenovirus. Adenoviruses, which usually cause cold- or flulike symptoms, are not typically associated with liver inflammation in healthy children.

item.title: Pope Francis says he will meet the head of the Russian Orthodox Church in September.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Patriarch Kirill I, left, and Pope Francis met in Havana in 2016. It was the first meeting between a pope and the head of the Russian Orthodox Church.

item.title: Police Arrest Owner of South African Tavern Where 21 Teenagers Died
item.description: Two employees were also arrested. Investigators have yet to say what killed the teenagers, who were found one June night collapsed in an overcrowded bar.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Forensic teams at the Enyobeni Tavern in East London, where 21 teenagers died.

item.title: Sunak Leads in U.K. Voting to Replace Prime Minister Boris Johnson
item.description: The former chancellor of the Exchequer led a pack of candidates after the first round, while an obscure trade minister surprised in second place.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak leaving the prime minister’s residence in May, when he was chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: Pope Names Three Women to Office That Helps Select Bishops
item.description: The three women will serve five-year terms in the Vatican office that vets candidates, enhancing the role of women in the church’s operations.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: A Vatican courtyard. One expert said the appointment of three women to a previously all-male committee would resonate throughout the church.

item.title: Bad Planning and Errors Led to Champions League Chaos, Report Says
item.description: A French Senate inquiry faulted the authorities for blaming large crowds of supporters instead of owning up to their failures, after violence and confusion marred a final near Paris.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Many Liverpool fans were unable to enter the Stade de France in time for the scheduled kickoff of the Champions League final in May, prompting officials to delay the start of the match.

item.title: Secret Service Employee Sent Home After Arrest in Israel
item.description: The employee had a “physical encounter,” a spokesman for the agency said, although it did not involve a sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden arrived in Jerusalem on Wednesday. A Secret Service team had preceded him in Israel.

item.title: Brittney Griner and the Limits of American Power
item.description: For Griner, and other Americans held prisoner overseas, the road home may be long, and slow.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Brittney Griner being escorted to a courtroom for a hearing, in Khimki outside Moscow, Russia, last week.

item.title: What Is Yad Vashem, Israel’s Holocaust Memorial?
item.description: President Biden met two survivors on a visit to Israel’s official Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: President Biden laying a wreath in the Hall of Remembrance at Yad Vashem on Wednesday. He also rekindled the eternal flame.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Acting President Has a Complicated Political History
item.description: A prime minister six times over, Ranil Wickremesinghe’s leadership has been equated with Sri Lanka’s economic ambitions as well as its collapse.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe of Sri Lanka at his office in Colombo, the country’s capital, in May.

item.title: Biden Sidesteps Request to Meet Family of Shireen Abu Akleh
item.description: The State Department instead invited Shireen Abu Akleh’s family to Washington, according to a U.S. official and the journalist’s brother.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the site where Shireen Abu Akleh was killed in the West Bank.

item.title: Who’s the Oldest of Them All?
item.description: Two towns in Sardinia battle for the distinction of having the longest-living residents. One has the imprimatur of Guinness World Records.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adolfo Melis, 99, is part of a family in Perdasdefogu, in Sardinia, that earned the Guinness World Record for the highest combined age of more than 800 years for nine living siblings.

item.title: Biden Adopts ‘No Handshake’ Covid Policy, but Not for Long
item.description: A virus subvariant provided a reason to “reduce contact” before a potentially fraught encounter with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia. The plan quickly slipped away in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Mr. Biden greeted Prime Minister Yair Lapid and President Isaac Herzog with fist bumps.
